name: Java Operators
description: Arithmetic, logical, bitwise, assignment, comparison, and other operators in Java.

questions.title: Arithmetic Operators
questions.description: What is the result of this expression?
questions.explanation: Due to operator precedence, multiplication is performed before addition: 5 * 2 = 10, then 10 + 10 = 20.

questions.title: Modulus Operator
questions.description: What does the modulus operator (%) return?
questions.explanation: The modulus operator returns the remainder of division. 17 รท 5 = 3 remainder 2, so 17 % 5 = 2.

questions.title: Increment Operators
questions.description: What is the difference between ++i and i++?
options: ++i increments before use, i++ increments after use
questions.explanation: ++i (pre-increment) increments the value before using it, while i++ (post-increment) uses the current value then increments it.

questions.title: Assignment Operators
questions.description: What is the value of x after this code executes?
questions.explanation: x += 5 makes x = 15, then x *= 2 makes x = 30. Compound assignment operators perform the operation and assign the result.

questions.title: Comparison Operators
questions.description: What is the result of this comparison?
questions.explanation: String literals are stored in the string pool, so both s1 and s2 reference the same object in memory, making == return true.

questions.title: Logical Operators
questions.description: What is the result of this logical expression?
questions.explanation: Due to operator precedence, && is evaluated before ||. So: (true && false) || true = false || true = true.

questions.title: Short-Circuit Evaluation
questions.description: What happens in short-circuit evaluation with &&?
questions.explanation: With &&, if the first operand is false, the second operand is not evaluated (short-circuit). So 10/0 is never executed.

questions.title: Bitwise AND Operator
questions.description: What is the result of this bitwise operation?
questions.explanation: 12 in binary is 1100, 10 in binary is 1010. Bitwise AND: 1100 & 1010 = 1000 = 8 in decimal.

questions.title: Bitwise OR Operator
questions.description: What is the result of this bitwise operation?
questions.explanation: 12 in binary is 1100, 10 in binary is 1010. Bitwise OR: 1100 | 1010 = 1110 = 14 in decimal.

questions.title: Bitwise XOR Operator
questions.description: What is the result of this bitwise operation?
questions.explanation: 12 in binary is 1100, 10 in binary is 1010. Bitwise XOR: 1100 ^ 1010 = 0110 = 6 in decimal.

questions.title: Left Shift Operator
questions.description: What is the result of this shift operation?
questions.explanation: Left shift by 2 positions is equivalent to multiplying by 2^2 = 4. So 5 << 2 = 5 * 4 = 20.

questions.title: Right Shift Operator
questions.description: What is the result of this shift operation?
questions.explanation: Right shift by 2 positions is equivalent to dividing by 2^2 = 4. So 20 >> 2 = 20 / 4 = 5.

questions.title: Ternary Operator
questions.description: What is the value of result?
questions.explanation: The ternary operator (condition ? value1 : value2) returns value2 (y=20) because x > y is false.

questions.title: Operator Precedence
questions.description: What is the result of this expression?
questions.explanation: Following operator precedence: 3 * 4 = 12, then 2 + 12 - 1 = 13.

questions.title: Unary Operators
questions.description: What is the value of x after this code?
questions.explanation: x = -x makes x = -5. Then x = ~x applies bitwise NOT. ~(-5) = ~(11111011) = 00000100 = 4.

questions.title: instanceof Operator
questions.description: What does the instanceof operator check?
questions.code:
String str = "Hello";
boolean result = str instanceof Object;
options: Whether object is instance of a type
questions.explanation: The instanceof operator checks if an object is an instance of a specific class or implements an interface. String extends Object, so this returns true.

questions.title: Compound Assignment
questions.description: What is equivalent to x += y?
questions.explanation: The compound assignment operator += is equivalent to x = x + y. It adds y to x and assigns the result back to x.

questions.title: Logical NOT Operator
questions.description: What is the result of this expression?
questions.explanation: a && b = true && false = false. Then !(false) = true. The NOT operator inverts the boolean value.

questions.title: Division by Zero
questions.description: What happens when you divide an integer by zero?
questions.explanation: Integer division by zero throws an ArithmeticException at runtime. This is different from floating-point division which returns infinity.

questions.title: Floating Point Division
questions.description: What is the result of this floating-point division?
questions.explanation: Floating-point division by zero returns positive or negative infinity, not an exception like integer division.

questions.title: String Concatenation
questions.description: What is the result of this expression?
questions.explanation: String concatenation is left-associative. "Hello" + 1 = "Hello1", then "Hello1" + 2 = "Hello12".

questions.title: Numeric Promotion
questions.description: What is the result type of this expression?
questions.explanation: In arithmetic operations, byte and short are promoted to int. The result of b + s is always at least an int.

questions.title: Bitwise Complement
questions.description: What is the result of the bitwise complement operator?
questions.explanation: Bitwise complement (~) flips all bits. For 5 (00000101), ~5 = 11111010 = -6 in two's complement representation.

questions.title: Unsigned Right Shift
questions.description: What is the difference between >> and >>> operators?
questions.explanation: >> is arithmetic right shift (preserves sign bit), while >>> is logical right shift (fills with zeros). For negative numbers, they produce different results.

questions.title: Operator Associativity
questions.description: What is the result of this expression?
questions.explanation: Subtraction is left-associative, so it's evaluated as (100 - 50) - 20 = 50 - 20 = 30.

questions.title: Boolean Operators vs Bitwise
questions.description: What's the difference between & and && operators?
questions.code:
boolean result = true & false;
boolean result2 = true && false;
questions.explanation: & always evaluates both operands, while && short-circuits (doesn't evaluate the second operand if the first is false).

questions.title: Equality vs Identity
questions.description: What's the difference between == and .equals()?
questions.explanation: == compares object references (identity), while .equals() compares object content (equality). Here a=false, b=true.

questions.title: Overflow Behavior
questions.description: What happens when an integer operation overflows?
questions.code:
int max = Integer.MAX_VALUE;
int result = max + 1;
questions.explanation: Integer overflow wraps around. When MAX_VALUE is exceeded, it wraps to MIN_VALUE. Java doesn't throw exceptions for integer overflow.

questions.title: Conditional Operator Chaining
questions.description: What is the value of result?
questions.explanation: Ternary operators can be chained. x=15: (15 < 10) is false, so check (15 < 20) which is true, returning "medium".

questions.title: Operator Overloading
questions.description: Which operators can be overloaded in Java?
questions.explanation: Java does not support operator overloading (except + for String concatenation which is built-in). You cannot define custom behavior for operators on user-defined classes.
